title: Gillian Coultard
text:
Gillian Coultard (born 22 July 1963) is a retired English <a href="Women%27s%20football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> player, and former England captain. She is one of <a href="England%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">England Women's</a> most <a href="Cap%20%28sports%29">capped</a> internationals, with 119 appearances, and was the highest capped outfield England international ever until <a href="Rachel%20Yankey">Rachel Yankey</a> reached 120 caps in 2012. At the time she was one of only five footballers (<a href="Bobby%20Moore">Bobby Moore</a>, <a href="Billy%20Wright%20%28footballer%20born%201924%29">Billy Wright</a>, <a href="Bobby%20Charlton">Bobby Charlton</a> and <a href="Peter%20Shilton">Peter Shilton</a> were the others) to have reached over 100 <a href="cap%20%28sport%29">caps</a> for England, and she was the first woman and amateur player to have done so.
International career.
Coultard, a <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> initially, though moving back to <a href="Sweeper%20%28association%20football%29">sweeper</a> towards the end of her career, made her international debut in a 3–1 win over the <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Republic of Ireland</a> in 1981, at the age of 18. She went on to score 30 goals at international level, a rate of one every four games, including a pair in England's first ever <a href="FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> finals match, a 3–2 win over <a href="Canada%20women%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">Canada</a> in <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a>, in 1995. England were knocked out at the quarter-final stage by eventual <a href="1995%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">tournament</a> runners-up, <a href="Germany%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Germany</a>. Coultard had also been part of the England squad which finished runners-up to <a href="Sweden%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a> in the <a href="1984%20European%20Competition%20for%20Women%27s%20Football">first UEFA final</a> in 1984, losing the final on <a href="Penalty%20shootout%20%28football%29">penalties</a>. Coultard was appointed England captain in 1991 when the previous captain <a href="Debbie%20Bampton">Debbie Bampton</a> was injured. Bampton was restored as captain in 1995, but Coultard regained the captaincy in 1997 when Bampton retired from international football.
Coultard won her 100th England cap in a 4–0 win over <a href="Scotland%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> at <a href="Almondvale%20Stadium">Almondvale Stadium</a> in August 1997. That October, before a <a href="1999%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">1999 World Cup qualifier</a> against <a href="Netherlands%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Holland</a> at <a href="Boleyn%20Ground">Upton Park</a>, she was presented with a silver cap by <a href="Geoff%20Hurst">Sir Geoff Hurst</a> in recognition of the achievement.
In the early stages of England's successful <a href="2001%20UEFA%20Women%27s%20Championship%20qualification">2001 UEFA Women's Championship qualification</a> campaign Coultard remained captain of the side. Coultard's 119th and final cap came in a 1–0 win over <a href="Switzerland%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Switzerland</a> in May 2000. She was later a non-playing member of the England side which suffered their record defeat – an 8–0 loss away to <a href="Norway%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Norway</a> in June 2000. In October 2000, 37-year-old Coultard announced her international retirement in order to concentrate on a coaching role in the National Women's Football Academy in <a href="Durham%2C%20England">Durham</a>.
Club career.
At club level, Coultard won two National League titles and six <a href="FA%20Women%27s%20Cup">FA Women's Cup</a> finals during 24 years with <a href="Doncaster%20Rovers%20Belles%20L.F.C.">Doncaster Belles</a>. Joining as a 13-year-old schoolgirl, she eventually made over 300 appearances and became a key player in the side which dominated women's football in England. She retired from club football at the end of the 2000–01 season, making an emotional farewell appearance for the Belles against <a href="Charlton%20Athletic%20L.F.C.">Charlton Athletic</a> in May 2001.
Coultard fitted in four training sessions and a match every week, despite her full–time job on the production line at a <a href="Pioneer%20Corporation">Pioneer</a> factory in <a href="Castleford">Castleford</a>. She used her annual leave from work to play for England and rejected several offers to join semi-professional clubs in <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a> and <a href="Finland">Finland</a>.
Post retirement.
In May 2005 Coultard was diagnosed with breast cancer, which was successfully treated with surgery, <a href="chemotherapy">chemotherapy</a> and <a href="Radiation%20therapy">radium therapy</a>. On 19 October 2006, she was inducted into the <a href="English%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">English Football Hall of Fame</a>. Coultard managed the new Hartlepool United Ladies team in 2008–09. In 2009, she was offered a role as coach of the <a href="Estonia%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Estonia women's national football team</a>, but turned down the offer for personal reasons.
Coultard was appointed <a href="Member%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">Member of the Order of the British Empire</a> (MBE) in the <a href="2021%20New%20Year%20Honours">2021 New Year Honours</a> for services to football.
